elements.content: With the aim of integrating the inherent chirality of ligand and the chirality induced by conformational twists of the asymmetric skeleton of the ligand upon its coordination, (1R,3S)-1,2,2-trimethyl-3-{[5-(2-hydroxy)phenyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl]}cyclopentanecarboxylic acid (H2L) was prepared from the acylation reaction of chiral camphoric acid with salicylhydrazide. The reactions of H2L with transition metal ions gave five coordination polymers {[Co(L)(py)2]·DMF} n (1), {[Ni(L)(py)2]·DMF} n (2), [Cu(L)(py)] n (3), [Zn2(L)2(py)2] n (4), and [Cd2(L)2(py)2] n (5). Complexes 1 and 2 show only right-handed helical chains with homochiral helical discrimination by interhelical nonclassic hydrogen bonds C–H···O. However, 3–5 contain right-handed and left-handed helical chains simultaneously, which are arranged alternately and interact with each other by π···π interactions for 3 and by interchain M–O–M linkage for 4 and 5, respectively. The chiralities of these compounds derive from the inherent chirality of the ligand, as well as from the conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton. The results also reveal the role of different metal ions in the construction of chiral coordination polymers. The fluorescent studies revealed emission bands assigned to intraligand transmission for complexes 1–5.

The reactions of H2L with transition metal ions gave five coordination polymers {[Co(L)(py)2]⋅DMF} n  (1), {[Ni(L)(py)2]⋅DMF} n  (2), [Cu(L)(py)] n  (3), [Zn2(L)2(py)2] n  (4), and [Cd2(L)2(py)2] n  (5). Complexes 1 and 2 show only right-handed helical chains with homochiral helical discrimination by interhelical nonclassic hydrogen bonds C-H⋅⋅⋅O. However, 3-5 contain right-handed and left-handed helical chains simultaneously, which are arranged alternately and interact with each other by π⋅⋅⋅π interactions for 3 and by interchain M-O-M linkage for 4 and 5, respectively. The chiralities of these compounds derive from the inherent chirality of the ligand, as well as from the conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton. The results also reveal the role of different metal ions in the construction of chiral coordination polymers. The fluorescent studies revealed emission bands assigned to intraligand transmission for complexes 1-5.

elements.content: The reactions of different metal ions with a new type of ligand gave five chiral coordination polymers, which integrate inherent molecular chiralities and helicities induced by conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton and show different interhelical interactions.
elements.clean_text: The reactions of different metal ions with a new type of ligand gave five chiral coordination polymers, which integrate inherent molecular chiralities and helicities induced by conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton and show different interhelical interactions.

elements.content: Chiral coordination polymers are of great current interest, not only because of their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies but also owing to their potential applications in fields such as asymmetric catalysis, recognition, separation, and nonlinear optics. Such chiral compounds can be achieved from chiral linkers or chiral auxiliary agents or from achiral reagents by spontaneous resolution via symmetry breaking crystallization in the presence or absence of inductive reagents and other inductive chiral physical environments such as polarized light. Among them, the most common approach is the rational combination of metal ion nodes bearing a specific coordination geometry with predesigned chiral multifunctional ligands, in which the chiral ligands link metal ions or just force chirality by coordinating to the metal centers as nonbridging ligands. Nevertheless, the use of achiral ligands to build different chiral organizations, especially by different conformational twists of the ligand skeleton, are also drawing more and more attention in recent years. One principal strategy for constructing these chiral materials is to build left- or right-handed helical structures, which requires an efficient transfer of stereochemical information between neighboring chiral helices. As demonstrated in the documents, supramolecular interactions including coordination bonds and noncovalent interactions, such as hydrogen bonds and π···π stacking interactions, contribute significantly in the transfer of chirality between helices. For this purpose, some special functional groups are to be attached to the ligand to favor these interactions and perform efficient chiral transfer throughout the supramolecular assembly. Although a lot of chiral coordination polymers have been reported, the study in interhelical chiral transfer at the supramolecular level is still in its infancy. Thus, an extensive study is to be undertaken for further understanding of this.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chiral coordination polymers are of great current interest, not only because of their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies but also owing to their potential applications in fields such as asymmetric catalysis, recognition, separation, and nonlinear optics. Such chiral compounds can be achieved from chiral linkers or chiral auxiliary agents or from achiral reagents by spontaneous resolution via symmetry breaking crystallization in the presence or absence of inductive reagents and other inductive chiral physical environments such as polarized light. Among them, the most common approach is the rational combination of metal ion nodes bearing a specific coordination geometry with predesigned chiral multifunctional ligands, in which the chiral ligands link metal ions or just force chirality by coordinating to the metal centers as nonbridging ligands. Nevertheless, the use of achiral ligands to build different chiral organizations, especially by different conformational twists of the ligand skeleton, are also drawing more and more attention in recent years. One principal strategy for constructing these chiral materials is to build left- or right-handed helical structures, which requires an efficient transfer of stereochemical information between neighboring chiral helices. As demonstrated in the documents, supramolecular interactions including coordination bonds and noncovalent interactions, such as hydrogen bonds and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions, contribute significantly in the transfer of chirality between helices. For this purpose, some special functional groups are to be attached to the ligand to favor these interactions and perform efficient chiral transfer throughout the supramolecular assembly. Although a lot of chiral coordination polymers have been reported, the study in interhelical chiral transfer at the supramolecular level is still in its infancy. Thus, an extensive study is to be undertaken for further understanding of this.

elements.content: On the basis of the above-mentioned studies, we set out to explore the synthesis of coordination polymers with helices from a new kind of chiral ligand which integrates the inherent chirality (chiral carbon atoms) and the chirality induced by conformational twists upon coordination. To effectively transfer the chiralities between helices to get high-dimensional chiral supramolecular assemblies, conjugated ring systems such as the phenyl group were introduced. Thus, we prepared (1R,3S)-1,2,2-trimethyl-3-{[5-(2-hydroxy)phenyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl]}cyclopentanecarboxylic acid (H2L) as the targeted ligand to make this study based on the following consideration. First, it contains chiral carbon atoms which can force their chiralities into the coordination compounds. Second, the flexible part and rigid part are connected by a C–C single bond, which facilitates the rotation of the rigid part around the single bond to form a locked twisted chiral conformation upon coordination. The reactions of H2L with transition metal ions gave five coordination polymers {[Co(L)(py)2]·DMF} n (1), {[Ni(L)(py)2]·DMF} n (2), [Cu(L)(py)] n (3), [Zn2(L)2(py)2] n (4), and [Cd2(L)2(py)2] n (5), which show different interhelical interactions for chiral transfer between helical chains and the role of different metal ions in the construction of chiral coordination polymers.

Thus, we prepared (1R,3S)-1,2,2-trimethyl-3-{[5-(2-hydroxy)phenyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl]}cyclopentanecarboxylic acid (H2L) as the targeted ligand to make this study based on the following consideration. First, it contains chiral carbon atoms which can force their chiralities into the coordination compounds. Second, the flexible part and rigid part are connected by a C-C single bond, which facilitates the rotation of the rigid part around the single bond to form a locked twisted chiral conformation upon coordination. The reactions of H2L with transition metal ions gave five coordination polymers {[Co(L)(py)2]⋅DMF} n  (1), {[Ni(L)(py)2]⋅DMF} n  (2), [Cu(L)(py)] n  (3), [Zn2(L)2(py)2] n  (4), and [Cd2(L)2(py)2] n  (5), which show different interhelical interactions for chiral transfer between helical chains and the role of different metal ions in the construction of chiral coordination polymers.

elements.content: All chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 500 spectrometer at 500.13 and 125.23 MHz, respectively. All proton and carbon chemical shifts are reported in δ units with reference to SiMe4. Mass spectra were recorded on a BRUKER ESQUIRE HCT spectrometer. Melting points were measured on a WRS-1A melting point apparatus and were uncorrected. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets using a PE Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 II analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected with a Rigaku D/max 2500v/pc diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Luminescence spectra were recorded on an Edinburgh Analytical Instrument FLS920 Luminescence spectrometer at room temperature. Circular dichroism (CD) spectra were determined on a FL3-PTCSPC CD spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 500 spectrometer at 500.13 and 125.23 MHz, respectively. All proton and carbon chemical shifts are reported in δ units with reference to SiMe4. Mass spectra were recorded on a BRUKER ESQUIRE HCT spectrometer. Melting points were measured on a WRS-1A melting point apparatus and were uncorrected. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets using a PE Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 II analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected with a Rigaku D/max 2500v/pc diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Luminescence spectra were recorded on an Edinburgh Analytical Instrument FLS920 Luminescence spectrometer at room temperature. Circular dichroism (CD) spectra were determined on a FL3-PTCSPC CD spectrometer.

elements.content: The newly prepared camphoric acid chloride (2.5 mmol, 0.5928 g) was added dropwise into a stirred THF solution (40 mL) of salicylhydrazide (0.76 g, 5 mmol) and NEt3 (0.6 mL) cooled by an ice bath under nitrogen atmosphere. Thirty minutes later, the resulting solution was allowed to warm to ambient temperature and was further stirred for another 40 h. Then, it was filtrated. The removal of solvent of the filtrate gave a crude product, which was purified by recrystallization from methanol and water and subsequent column chromatography by ethyl acetate/petroleum ether (1: 2.5), giving a white product of H2L in an overall yield of 0.45 g (60%). Mp: 185–187 °C. Anal. Calcd for C17H20N2O4 (316.35): C, 64.54; H, 6.37; N, 8.86. elements.content: H2L (0.0316 g, 0.1 mmol), Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.0750 g, 0.3 mmol), DMF (0.5 mL), and pyridine (0.5 mL) were sealed in a 20 cm long Pyrex tube after being frozen by liquid nitrogen and subsequent evacuation. The Pyrex tube was allowed to warm and then heated at 60 °C. Three days later, it was cooled slowly to ambient temperature, producing red crystals in a yield of 40%. Anal. Calcd for C30H35CoN5O5 (604.56): C, 59.60; H, 5.84; N, 11.58. Found: C, 59.37; H, 5.68; N, 11.73. νmax (KBr pellet)/cm–1: 3435m, 2961m, 2895w, 1678m, 1609s, 1540s, 1475s, 1444s, 1266m, 1038m, 855m, 754s.

elements.content: A pyridine solution (5 mL) of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.0600 g, 0.3 mmol) was added dropwise to a DMF (5 mL) solution of H2L (0.0316 g, 0.1 mmol) while being stirred. The slow evaporation of the deep green filtrate at ambient temperature for 20 days gave green crystals in a yield of 30%. Anal. Calcd for C22H23CuN3O4 (456.97): C, 57.82; H, 5.07; N, 9.20. The resulting solution was further stirred at ambient temperature for 8 h and then filtrated. The slow evaporation of the deep green filtrate at ambient temperature for 20 days gave green crystals in a yield of 30%. Anal. Calcd for C22H23CuN3O4 (456.97): C, 57.82; H, 5.07; N, 9.20. X-ray single-crystal data of 1–5 were collected using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer. Absorption correction were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods of SHELXS-97 and were refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2, using the SHELXL-97 program or the corresponding programs in the SHELXTL package. After all of the non-H atoms were located, the model was refined again, initially using isotropic and later anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. H atoms attached to C atoms were included in geometrically calculated positions for all structures using a riding model and were refined isotropically. Experimental details for the structure analysis of 1–5 are given in Table . The selected bond distances and angles for 1–5 are listed in Tables S1 and S2 of the .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Refinement

X-ray single-crystal data of 1-5 were collected using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer. Absorption correction were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods of SHELXS-97 and were refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2, using the SHELXL-97 program or the corresponding programs in the SHELXTL package. After all of the non-H atoms were located, the model was refined again, initially using isotropic and later anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. H atoms attached to C atoms were included in geometrically calculated positions for all structures using a riding model and were refined isotropically. Experimental details for the structure analysis of 1-5 are given in Table . The selected bond distances and angles for 1-5 are listed in Tables S1 and S2 of the .

elements.content: The condensation reaction of newly prepared camphoric acid chloride with salicylhydrazide in THF gave (1R,3S)-1,2,2-trimethyl-3-{[5-(2-hydroxy)phenyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl]}-cyclopentane-carboxylic acid (H2L), as shown in Scheme , which was characterized by IR, EA, and NMR spectroscopy. Its reactions with Co(II), Ni(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) acetate provide a series of chiral metal complexes of L2– with different topological structures. The phase purities of the microcrystals of 1–5 were confirmed by the nice agreement of their experimental PXRD patterns with the simulated ones based on their crystal structures (Figures S1–S5 of the ), respectively. The L2– ligands in the five complexes present two kinds of bridging modes, as shown in Scheme .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

The condensation reaction of newly prepared camphoric acid chloride with salicylhydrazide in THF gave (1R,3S)-1,2,2-trimethyl-3-{[5-(2-hydroxy)phenyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl]}-cyclopentane-carboxylic acid (H2L), as shown in Scheme , which was characterized by IR, EA, and NMR spectroscopy. Its reactions with Co(II), Ni(II), Cu(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) acetate provide a series of chiral metal complexes of L2- with different topological structures. The phase purities of the microcrystals of 1-5 were confirmed by the nice agreement of their experimental PXRD patterns with the simulated ones based on their crystal structures (Figures S1-S5 of the ), respectively. The L2- ligands in the five complexes present two kinds of bridging modes, as shown in Scheme .

elements.content: The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of 1–5 in KBr pellets were recorded at room temperature, as shown in Figure S6 of the , respectively. They show clear optical rotation spectra. The repeated measurements on the crystals from different batches of these complexes presented similar CD curves. The distinct CD signals confirm the chirality of the bulk crystals of complexes 1–5.

elements.content: X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis results reveal that 1 and 2 crystallize in the orthorhombic space group P212121 with similar structures. Thus only the structure of 2 was described here in detail. As shown in Figure , the Ni(II) ion in 2 is six-coordinated in octahedral geometry completed by three oxygen atoms and three nitrogen atoms from two L2– ligands and two pyridine molecules. The Ni–O and Ni–N bond lengths [1.994(3) – 2.148(3) Å] are in a normal range. Each L2– ligand bridges two Ni(II) ions via chelation, behaving as a μ2-η2:η2-bridge, as shown in Scheme . This kind of interaction leads to the construction of an infinite right-handed helical chain with the nearest Ni···Ni distance of 11.0216(3) Å and a pitch of 12.9184(5) Å, as shown in Figure (panels a and b). Adjacent helical chains in the ab plane interact with each other by three kinds of nonclassic hydrogen bonds, C–H···O (Table S1 of the ), to form two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular sheets (Figure S7 of the ), which are further connected by one kind of nonclassic hydrogen bonds, C–H···O (Table S1 of the ), to form a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (Figure c).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 1-5 

X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis results reveal that 1 and 2 crystallize in the orthorhombic space group P212121 with similar structures. Thus only the structure of 2 was described here in detail. As shown in Figure , the Ni(II) ion in 2 is six-coordinated in octahedral geometry completed by three oxygen atoms and three nitrogen atoms from two L2- ligands and two pyridine molecules. The Ni-O and Ni-N bond lengths [1.994(3) - 2.148(3) Å] are in a normal range. Each L2- ligand bridges two Ni(II) ions via chelation, behaving as a μ2-η2:η2-bridge, as shown in Scheme . This kind of interaction leads to the construction of an infinite right-handed helical chain with the nearest Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance of 11.0216(3) Å and a pitch of 12.9184(5) Å, as shown in Figure  (panels a and b). Adjacent helical chains in the ab plane interact with each other by three kinds of nonclassic hydrogen bonds, C-H⋅⋅⋅O (Table S1 of the ), to form two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular sheets (Figure S7 of the ), which are further connected by one kind of nonclassic hydrogen bonds, C-H⋅⋅⋅O (Table S1 of the ), to form a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (Figure c).

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in a chiral space group P21 with two crystallographically independent [Cu(L)(py)] moieties in its asymmetric unit, as shown in Figure . The two Cu(II) ions (Cu1 and Cu2) show similar square pyramidal geometries completed by three oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two L2– ligands and one pyridine molecule. The apical site is occupied by one carboxylato oxygen atom with a rather long Cu–O bond length. The corresponding Cu–O and Cu–N bond lengths reveal apparent Jahn–Teller effects for the two Cu(II) ions. This might be the real reason for the difference of 3 from 1 and 2. Similar to 1 and 2, the L2– ligand in 3 also acts as a μ2-η2:η2-bridge connecting two Cu(II) ions. This kind of interaction results in the connection of adjacent Cu1 ions or Cu2 ions by L2– ligands with the neighboring Cu1···Cu1 and Cu2···Cu2 distances of 10.848(2) and 10.828(2) Å, respectively, giving rise to two kinds of helical chains (Figure ) with the same helical pitch of 11.466(2) Å. The Cu1 helical chain is left-handed and the Cu2 helical chain is right-handed. The two kinds of chains are alternately arranged in the (101̅) plane in an ABA­BAB manner. The neighboring phenyl rings from the adjacent chains are nearly parallel to each other with a small dihedral angle of 0.848(1)° and a center-to-center distance of 3.6202(2) Å, suggesting the presence of π···π stacking interactions between the two phenyl rings. This helps to construct a supramolecular 2D sheet (Figure a) in the (101̅) plane with the nearest interchain Cu···Cu distance of 7.134(2) Å. The neighboring N5 pyridyl ring and N6 pyridyl ring from the two adjacent 2D supramolecular sheets interact with each other via π···π stacking interactions, as revealed by a small dihedral angle of 1.514° and a center-to-center distance of 3.7093(2) Å. This leads to the interlayer connection of left-handed helical chains to right-handed helical chains, constructing a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure b).

elements.content: Compounds 4 and 5 crystallize in the monoclinic space group P21 with similar structures, thus only the structure of 5 was discussed here in detail. There are two Cd(II) ions, two L2– ligands, and two pyridine molecules in the asymmetric unit of 5, as depicted in Figure . The two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions are hexa-coordinated with a N2O4 donor set from three L2– ligands and one pyridine molecule. The coordination environment is best described as a distorted octahedron. The Cd–N [2.279(7)–2.328(6) Å] and Cd–O bond lengths [2.250(5)–2.374(5) Å] are in the normal range. Cd1 and Cd2 are double bridged by two phenolic oxygen atoms from two L2– ligands, constructing a dinuclear secondary building block with a Cd···Cd distance of 3.4755(5) Å. The two carboxylato groups in each dinuclear secondary building block chelate to another two Cd(II) ions from two neighboring secondary building blocks, and the two Cd(II) ions in each dinuclear secondary building block are in turn chelated by another two carboxylato groups from two neighboring secondary building blocks. As a result, each dinuclear secondary building block was linked to another four, leading to the construction of a 2D sheet (Figure ). An important feature is that the right-handed and left-handed helical chains are arranged alternately in the 2D framework. The adjacent Cd(II) ions from the neighboring helical chains are double bridged by two phenolic oxygen atoms. Both of the two kinds of helical chains have a pitch of 13.5650(9) Å. It is easy to conclude that each L2– ligand in 5 behaves as a μ3-η2:η2:η1-bridge, as shown in Scheme b. A packing diagram of the 2D sheets in 5 is shown in Figure S8 of the , in which no significant weak interactions are found between the adjacent sheets.

elements.content: The designed ligand in this study contains not only chiral carbon atoms but also an asymmetric ligand skeleton, in which the flexible part and rigid part can rotate around the C–C single bond to form locked twisted chiral conformations upon coordination, as shown in Scheme . This leads to the integration of inherent molecular chirality and absolute helicity in the titled complexes, exhibiting dual chiral features. The inherent molecular chirality of the H2L ligand was retained in the five complexes. However, the absolute helicities derived from the conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton and the interhelical interactions vary significantly in these complexes, as shown in Scheme . Complexes 1 and 2 present only one kind of helical chain (right-handed helical chain). The adjacent chains in 1 and 2 interact with each other via interhelical nonclassic hydrogen bonds C–H···O, performing homochiral helical discrimination. However, two kinds of helical chains with opposite handedness (right- and left-handed helical chains) were found in 3–5. The right- and left-handed helical chains in 3 are arranged alternately to form first a supramolecular 2D and then a 3D structure by interhelical π···π interactions. Different from that for 3, the interhelical connection in the layer of 4 and 5 is fulfilled by M–O–M coordination linkages between right- and left-handed helical chains. The single crystal X-ray diffractional analysis results reveal that the helical chains and their absolute helicity in these compounds are derived from the conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton via the rotation of the C–C single bond, as shown in Scheme . This is much different from the reported cases in which the absolute helicity is controlled by the handedness of the enantiopure ligand. Thus, both inherent chirality of the ligand and the fixed conformational twist of the asymmetric ligand skeleton upon its coordination contribute significantly in the occurrence of the overall chirality of 1 and 2. It is shown in documents that the alternate arrangement of right- and left-handed helical chains usually affords internal racemate or achiral compounds. However, compounds 3–5 are chiral as stated in the context. The overall net chiralities of compounds 3–5 are largely derived from the inherent chiralities of the ligand (chiral carbon atoms). The above-mentioned difference in the five complexes might be caused by the nature of different metal ions, including the different electronic configuration and the thus resulted in different coordination environments of metal ions. The Co(II) and Ni(II) ions in 1 and 2 exhibit nearly regular six-coordinate MN3O3 octahedral geometry with one pyridine molecule in the equatorial position and the other in the axial position. From their comparison to the Cu(II) complex (3), it is easy to see that this kind of case hinders the formation of interhelical π···π stacking interactions but favors the formation of nonclassic hydrogen bonds C–H···O as interhelical interactions. The Cu(II) ion in 3 display an elongated “4 + 1” geometry for the presence of the Jahn–Teller effect, which leads to the facile formation of π···π stacking interactions as the interhelical linkage. The Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions in 4 and 5 have closed d electronic shells. Their participation in coordination with H2L in this system leads to a linking mode of L2– different from those in 1–3; that is, the phenolic oxygen atom in L2– ligand of 4 and 5 acts as a μ2-linker bridging two metal ions from adjacent helical chains. This means that the adjacent helical chains are connected by interchain M–O–M coordination linkages. Obviously, different metal ions play vital roles in the interhelical interactions in these compounds via tuning the coordination environments and the linking modes of the L2– ligand.
elements.clean_text: The designed ligand in this study contains not only chiral carbon atoms but also an asymmetric ligand skeleton, in which the flexible part and rigid part can rotate around the C-C single bond to form locked twisted chiral conformations upon coordination, as shown in Scheme . This leads to the integration of inherent molecular chirality and absolute helicity in the titled complexes, exhibiting dual chiral features. The inherent molecular chirality of the H2L ligand was retained in the five complexes. However, the absolute helicities derived from the conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton and the interhelical interactions vary significantly in these complexes, as shown in Scheme . Complexes 1 and 2 present only one kind of helical chain (right-handed helical chain). The adjacent chains in 1 and 2 interact with each other via interhelical nonclassic hydrogen bonds C-H⋅⋅⋅O, performing homochiral helical discrimination. However, two kinds of helical chains with opposite handedness (right- and left-handed helical chains) were found in 3-5. The right- and left-handed helical chains in 3 are arranged alternately to form first a supramolecular 2D and then a 3D structure by interhelical π⋅⋅⋅π interactions. Different from that for 3, the interhelical connection in the layer of 4 and 5 is fulfilled by M-O-M coordination linkages between right- and left-handed helical chains. The single crystal X-ray diffractional analysis results reveal that the helical chains and their absolute helicity in these compounds are derived from the conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton via the rotation of the C-C single bond, as shown in Scheme . This is much different from the reported cases in which the absolute helicity is controlled by the handedness of the enantiopure ligand. Thus, both inherent chirality of the ligand and the fixed conformational twist of the asymmetric ligand skeleton upon its coordination contribute significantly in the occurrence of the overall chirality of 1 and 2. It is shown in documents that the alternate arrangement of right- and left-handed helical chains usually affords internal racemate or achiral compounds. However, compounds 3-5 are chiral as stated in the context. The overall net chiralities of compounds 3-5 are largely derived from the inherent chiralities of the ligand (chiral carbon atoms). The above-mentioned difference in the five complexes might be caused by the nature of different metal ions, including the different electronic configuration and the thus resulted in different coordination environments of metal ions. The Co(II) and Ni(II) ions in 1 and 2 exhibit nearly regular six-coordinate MN3O3 octahedral geometry with one pyridine molecule in the equatorial position and the other in the axial position. From their comparison to the Cu(II) complex (3), it is easy to see that this kind of case hinders the formation of interhelical π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions but favors the formation of nonclassic hydrogen bonds C-H⋅⋅⋅O as interhelical interactions. The Cu(II) ion in 3 display an elongated "4 + 1" geometry for the presence of the Jahn-Teller effect, which leads to the facile formation of π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions as the interhelical linkage. The Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions in 4 and 5 have closed d  electronic shells. Their participation in coordination with H2L in this system leads to a linking mode of L2- different from those in 1-3; that is, the phenolic oxygen atom in L2- ligand of 4 and 5 acts as a μ2-linker bridging two metal ions from adjacent helical chains. This means that the adjacent helical chains are connected by interchain M-O-M coordination linkages. Obviously, different metal ions play vital roles in the interhelical interactions in these compounds via tuning the coordination environments and the linking modes of the L2- ligand.

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of free ligand and complexes 1–5 were investigated in solid state at room temperature, as shown in Figure . The free ligand exhibits band with maximum at 423 nm upon excitation at 358 nm, which is assigned to intraligand π → π* charge transfer. Complexes 1–5 show maximum emissions at 443, 459, 440, 413, and 413 nm when excited at 358 nm, respectively. Obviously, the emission of 1–5 are due to intraligand charge transfer. The differences in intensities and shift for the emission peaks of these complexes are probably due to the differences of electronic configurations of the M(II) centers, as well as different coordination modes of ligands in these complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The photoluminescent properties of free ligand and complexes 1-5 were investigated in solid state at room temperature, as shown in Figure . The free ligand exhibits band with maximum at 423 nm upon excitation at 358 nm, which is assigned to intraligand π → π* charge transfer. Complexes 1-5 show maximum emissions at 443, 459, 440, 413, and 413 nm when excited at 358 nm, respectively. Obviously, the emission of 1-5 are due to intraligand charge transfer. The differences in intensities and shift for the emission peaks of these complexes are probably due to the differences of electronic configurations of the M(II) centers, as well as different coordination modes of ligands in these complexes.

elements.content: In conclusion, five chiral coordination polymers bearing helical chains were constructed from the reactions of a series of transition metal ions with (1R,3S)-1,2,2-trimethyl-3-{[5-(2-hydroxy)phenyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl]}-cyclopentanecarboxylic acid (H2L), which incorporates the inherent chirality of ligand and the helicities induced by conformational twists of its asymmetric skeleton upon its coordination. It also reveals an important contribution of different metal ions on the construction of these chiral coordination polymers and different interhelical interactions in these compounds. Complexes 1 and 2 show just right-handed helical chain structures with interhelical nonclassic hydrogen bonds C–H···O for homochiral helical discrimination. Right- and left-handed helical chains in the layer are interacted alternately by interhelical π···π interactions in 3 and by interhelical M–O–M linkage in 4 and 5, respectively. The chiralities of these compounds can be explained for the combination of the inherent chirality of the ligand and the conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton upon coordination. This provides a new strategy for further exploration of chiral coordination polymers. An investigation of the fluorescent properties of complexes 1–5 and the free ligand indicates that the emission bands of these complexes are due to the intraligand transmission.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, five chiral coordination polymers bearing helical chains were constructed from the reactions of a series of transition metal ions with (1R,3S)-1,2,2-trimethyl-3-{[5-(2-hydroxy)phenyl-1,3,4-oxadiazol-2-yl]}-cyclopentanecarboxylic acid (H2L), which incorporates the inherent chirality of ligand and the helicities induced by conformational twists of its asymmetric skeleton upon its coordination. It also reveals an important contribution of different metal ions on the construction of these chiral coordination polymers and different interhelical interactions in these compounds. Complexes 1 and 2 show just right-handed helical chain structures with interhelical nonclassic hydrogen bonds C-H⋅⋅⋅O for homochiral helical discrimination. Right- and left-handed helical chains in the layer are interacted alternately by interhelical π⋅⋅⋅π interactions in 3 and by interhelical M-O-M linkage in 4 and 5, respectively. The chiralities of these compounds can be explained for the combination of the inherent chirality of the ligand and the conformational twists of the asymmetric ligand skeleton upon coordination. This provides a new strategy for further exploration of chiral coordination polymers. An investigation of the fluorescent properties of complexes 1-5 and the free ligand indicates that the emission bands of these complexes are due to the intraligand transmission.

The newly prepared camphoric acid chloride (2.5 mmol, 0.5928 g) was added dropwise into a stirred THF solution (40 mL) of salicylhydrazide (0.76 g, 5 mmol) and NEt3 (0.6 mL) cooled by an ice bath under nitrogen atmosphere. Thirty minutes later, the resulting solution was allowed to warm to ambient temperature and was further stirred for another 40 h. Then, it was filtrated. The removal of solvent of the filtrate gave a crude product, which was purified by recrystallization from methanol and water and subsequent column chromatography by ethyl acetate/petroleum ether (1: 2.5), giving a white product of H2L in an overall yield of 0.45 g (60%). Mp: 185–187 °C. Anal. Calcd for C17H20N2O4 (316.35): C, 64.54; H, 6.37; N, 8.86. Found: C, 64.33; H, 6.24; N, 8.97. νmax (KBr pellet)/cm–1: 3412m, 2978m, 2964m, 2890w, 1692vs, 1627s, 1548s, 1490s, 1473m, 1252m, 1157m, 1077m, 972m, 752m. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 12.28 (m, 1H, COOH), 10.23 (s, 1H, OH), 7.74 (d, 1H, 3 J = 7.5 Hz, ArH), 7.45 (t, 1H, 3 J = 7.5 Hz, ArH), 7.07 (d, 1H, 3 J = 8.0 Hz, ArH), 7.00 (t, 1H, 3 J = 8.0 Hz, ArH), 3.52 (t, 1H, 3 J = 9.5 Hz, −CHC(CH3)2−), 2.57 (m, 1H, −CH 2−), 2.30 (m, 1H, −CH 2−), 2.10 (m, 1H, −CH 2−), 1.54 (m, 1H, −CH 2−), 1.25 (s, 6H, C(CH 3)2), 0.68 (s, 3H, CH 3). 13C NMR (125.8 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 177.0, 167.2, 164.1, 156.7, 133.7, 128.8, 120.2, 117.4, 110.0, 55.7, 47.0, 44.9, 32.6, 23.4, 22.5, 22.2, 21.2. [M–H]−: 314.98.

Synthesis of {[Co(L)(py)<sub>2</sub>]·DMF}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

H2L (0.0316 g, 0.1 mmol), Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.0750 g, 0.3 mmol), DMF (0.5 mL), and pyridine (0.5 mL) were sealed in a 20 cm long Pyrex tube after being frozen by liquid nitrogen and subsequent evacuation. The Pyrex tube was allowed to warm and then heated at 60 °C. Three days later, it was cooled slowly to ambient temperature, producing red crystals in a yield of 40%. Anal. Calcd for C30H35CoN5O5 (604.56): C, 59.60; H, 5.84; N, 11.58. Found: C, 59.37; H, 5.68; N, 11.73. νmax (KBr pellet)/cm–1: 3435m, 2961m, 2895w, 1678m, 1609s, 1540s, 1475s, 1444s, 1266m, 1038m, 855m, 754s.

Synthesis of {[Ni(L)(py)<sub>2</sub>]·DMF}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was prepared in a way similar to that of 1 using Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.0750 g, 0.3 mmol) instead of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O. Product 2 presents red crystals. Yield: 45%. Anal. Calcd for C30H35NiN5O5 (604.34): C, 59.62; H, 5.84; N, 11.59. Found: C, 59.35; H, 5.71; N, 11.76. νmax (KBr pellet)/cm–1: 3407m, 2963m, 2884w, 1659w, 1611s, 1536s, 1476s, 1446s, 1268m, 1039m, 859m, 754s.

Synthesis of [Cu(L)(py)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A pyridine solution (5 mL) of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O (0.0600 g, 0.3 mmol) was added dropwise to a DMF (5 mL) solution of H2L (0.0316 g, 0.1 mmol) while being stirred. The resulting solution was further stirred at ambient temperature for 8 h and then filtrated. The slow evaporation of the deep green filtrate at ambient temperature for 20 days gave green crystals in a yield of 30%. Anal. Calcd for C22H23CuN3O4 (456.97): C, 57.82; H, 5.07; N, 9.20. Found: C, 58.06; H, 5.18; N, 9.36. νmax (KBr pellet)/cm–1: 3432m, 2967m, 2879w, 1668w, 1616s, 1560s, 1476s, 1384m, 1272m, 1040m, 863m, 750s.

Synthesis of [Zn<sub>2</sub>(L)<sub>2</sub>(py)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

Compound 4 was prepared in a way similar to that of 3, using Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.0660 g, 0.3 mmol) instead of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O. The final product of 4 is colorless crystals in a yield of 35%. Anal. Calcd for C44H46Zn2N6O8 (917.61): C, 57.59; H, 5.05; N, 9.16. Found: C, 57.37; H, 5.14; N, 8.99. νmax (KBr pellet)/cm–1: 3435(m), 2969m, 2884w, 1657w, 1610s, 1546s, 1480s, 1451s, 1315m, 1242s, 1071m, 854m, 756s.

Synthesis of [Cd<sub>2</sub>(L)<sub>2</sub>(py)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

Compound 5 was prepared in a way similar to that of 3 using Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.0800 g, 0.3 mmol) instead of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O. It affords 5 as colorless crystals in a yield of 40%. Anal. Calcd for C44H46Cd2N6O8 (1011.67): C, 52.24; H, 4.58; N, 8.31. Found: C, 51.97; H, 4.46; N, 8.49. νmax (KBr pellet)/cm–1: 3421m, 2969m, 1651w, 1605s, 1537s, 1476s, 1408m, 1315m, 1230m, 1039m, 854m, 754m.

<label>2</label>
<caption>
<title>Coordination
Modes of L<sup>2–</sup> in Compounds <bold>1</bold>–<bold>5</bold>
</title>
</caption>

</fig>
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination Modes of L2- in Compounds 1-5

cln_elements.content: Molecular structure of 2 with displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: A, −x + 1, y – 1/2, −z + 1/2; B, −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Molecular structure of 2 with displacement ellipsoids drawn at the 30% probability level. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: A, -x + 1, y - 1/2, -z + 1/2; B, -x + 1, y + 1/2, -z + 1/2.

cln_elements.content: (a) A view of the 1D chain of 2. (b) Space-filling view of the right-handed helical chain of 2. (c) Ball-and-stick diagram of the 3D supramolecular framework of 2 constructed from helical chains (highlighted by different colors) by nonclassic hydrogen bonds with intrahelical, intralayer, and interlayer hydrogen bonds represented by yellow, violet, and blue broken lines, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) A view of the 1D chain of 2. (b) Space-filling view of the right-handed helical chain of 2. (c) Ball-and-stick diagram of the 3D supramolecular framework of 2 constructed from helical chains (highlighted by different colors) by nonclassic hydrogen bonds with intrahelical, intralayer, and interlayer hydrogen bonds represented by yellow, violet, and blue broken lines, respectively.

cln_elements.content: ORTEP view of the structure of 3 showing the atom-labeling scheme and 30% thermal ellipsoids. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: A, −x + 1, y – 1/2, −z + 2; B, −x, y + 1/2, −z + 1; C, −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 2; D, −x, y – 1/2, −z + 1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  ORTEP view of the structure of 3 showing the atom-labeling scheme and 30% thermal ellipsoids. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: A, -x + 1, y - 1/2, -z + 2; B, -x, y + 1/2, -z + 1; C, -x + 1, y + 1/2, -z + 2; D, -x, y - 1/2, -z + 1.

cln_elements.content: (a) Two-dimensional supramolecular sheet built from alternately arranged left- and right-handed chains by π···π stacking interactions. (b) Three-dimensional supramolecular framework of 3 constructed from 2D supramolecular sheets by π–π stacking interactions.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Two-dimensional supramolecular sheet built from alternately arranged left- and right-handed chains by π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions. (b) Three-dimensional supramolecular framework of 3 constructed from 2D supramolecular sheets by π-π stacking interactions.

cln_elements.content: ORTEP view of the structure of 5 with 30% thermal ellipsoids and selected atoms labeled. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: A, −x, y + 1/2, −z; B, −x + 1, y – 1/2, −z + 1; C, −x + 1, y + 1/2, −z + 1; D, −x, y – 1/2, −z.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  ORTEP view of the structure of 5 with 30% thermal ellipsoids and selected atoms labeled. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: A, -x, y + 1/2, -z; B, -x + 1, y - 1/2, -z + 1; C, -x + 1, y + 1/2, -z + 1; D, -x, y - 1/2, -z.

cln_elements.content: (a) View of the 2D framework of 5 with alternately arranged right- and left-handed helical chains highlighted by red and light blue colors, respectively. (b) View of the 2D framework of 5 with helical chains highlighted by space-filling diagrams. The interchain M–O–M coordination linkages are highlighted in green.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (a) View of the 2D framework of 5 with alternately arranged right- and left-handed helical chains highlighted by red and light blue colors, respectively. (b) View of the 2D framework of 5 with helical chains highlighted by space-filling diagrams. The interchain M-O-M coordination linkages are highlighted in green.
